definition: smell of gunpowder/(fig.) combative tone/belligerence
fire/urgent/ammunition/fiery or flaming/internal heat (Chinese medicine)/hot (popular)/classifier for military units (old)/Kangxi radical 86
surname Huo
medicine/drug/substance used for a specific purpose (e.g. poisoning, explosion, fermenting)/CL:種|种[zhong3],服[fu4],味[wei4]/to poison
taste/smell/(fig.) (noun suffix) feel/quality/sense/(TCM) classifier for ingredients of a medicine prescription
strong smell of gunpowder/fig. tense situation/standoff

sentences.english: I can smell the gunpowder all the way up here in the cockpit.
sentences.chinese: 一路上我都可以從駕駛艙裏聞到火藥味。

sentences.english: It was a day of tense and often ill- tempered debate.
sentences.chinese: 那天的辯論緊張激烈，常常火藥味十足。

sentences.english: This is perhaps the most militarized Buddhist enclave in the world.
sentences.chinese: 這裏或許是世界上火藥味最濃的佛教地區。

sentences.english: "To give lip" means to be too militant in your speech.
sentences.chinese: “說硬話”是指講話火藥味太濃。

sentences.english: On that exciting night, air was filled with a strong smell of gunpowder .
sentences.chinese: 在那個激動人心的夜晚，空氣中充滿了火藥味。

sentences.english: And they will look at your hands. You smell of powder. Shot.
sentences.chinese: 他們會叫你伸出手來看，發現手上有火藥味，就槍斃。

sentences.english: He teed off on the selection committee in an illtempered article.
sentences.chinese: 他在一篇火藥味很濃的文章中攻擊選拔委員會。

definition: to oppose each other with equal harshness (idiom); tit for tat/measure for measure
lit. the salted fish turns over (idiom)/fig. to experience a reversal of fortune
to fight openly and maneuver covertly (idiom)
hissing sound/to hiss (as a sign of displeasure)
vocal accompaniment in some traditional Chinese operas/to speak in support of/to chime in
to shoot accidentally while polishing a gun/(fig.) a minor incident that sparks a war
elated and excited (idiom); overjoyed
lit. you hoodwink me and I cheat you (idiom); fig. mutual deception/each tries to outwit the other/dog eats dog and devil take the hindmost
to be drowned (figurative and literal)
to suffer defeat in every battle (idiom)
gongs and drums overture to a Chinese opera/to create a disturbance
the content of a conversation/words/remarks
seize every minute and second (idiom); not a minute to lose/every moment counts
outward devotion but inner opposition (idiom); to pay lip service/to agree overtly, but oppose in secret
fight a battle of words/cross verbal swords
danger lurks on every side (idiom)
